intro: Paepalanthus microphyllus, commonly known as the small-leaved puya, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Xanthorrhoeaceae family and is characterized by its rosette-forming leaves and striking inflorescences. The plant produces small, colorful flowers that are typically arranged in dense, spike-like clusters. It is adapted to high-altitude environments and thrives in well-drained soils. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens for its ornamental value.
